page.title: 09WOODLAND
page.content: To the west of Tilehurst lies the biggest patch of woodland in this area.The wood gets its name from the little village of Sulham which nestles at the bottom of Sulham Hill one of the steepest hills around here. The parish of Sulham is a true Anglo_Saxon parish and is recorded in the original Domesday Book.The name comes from the Saxon word Sulh,meaning a steep sided valley and the word Ham describes a hamlet in the valley. The wood has survived both farming and building because it covers a steep,chalk escarpment and is now run by the Forestry Commision,although it still belongs to the Wilder family of Sulham Estates and has done since the 15th Century.There is public access to the woodland and visitors can enjoy walks amongst the trees.
